bioghist.head: Historical Information
bioghist.p: Chancery Causes are cases of equity. According to Black's Law Dictionary they are "administered according to fairness as contrasted with the strictly formulated rules of common law." A judge, not a jury, determines the outcome of the case.

Richmond, located between Henrico and Chesterfield Counties, was named by William Byrd II, who envisioned the development of a city at the falls of the James River and with the help of William Mayo laid out the town in 1737. It was incorporated as a town in 1782 and as a city in 1842.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Richmond (Va.) Chancery Cause, Attorney General vs. Bradley, etc., 1828-1829. The collection consists of affidavits and genealogies of the Bradley family of Lansdale, York County, England. The records pertain to claims by the Bradley family of England on the estate of Thomas H. Bradley, who died in Richmond in 1826. A note indicates the records were found in the office of a Mr. Leigh in 1850 and taken to the chancery office, where it was learned "that the suit of the Attorney General vs. Bradley, etc., had been long since decided."
